unnormalised: It all started last Diwali. My grandfather, Shri. Rakesh Kumar, a vibrant 75-year-old, suddenly clutched his chest. We rushed him to Fortis Hospital, Bannerghatta Road, around 11:30 PM. The ER doctor, Dr. Sharma, immediately ordered an ECG.
normalised: It all started last Diwali. My grandfather, Shri. Rakesh Kumar, a vibrant seventy five year old, suddenly clutched his chest. We rushed him to Fortis Hospital, Bannerghatta Road, around eleven thirty P.M. The E-R doctor, Doctor Sharma, immediately ordered an E-C-G.

unnormalised: The diagnosis came as a shock: acute myocardial infarction. A heart attack. It was a bolt from the blue, as he'd always seemed hale and hearty. He was a regular walker, ate mostly vegetarian food, and only indulged in chai and biscuits once a day. Dr. Sharma explained that a blockage, likely due to years of subtle plaque buildup, had cut off blood supply to a part of his heart.

unnormalised: He was immediately prepped for an angioplasty. The procedure, scheduled for 8:00 AM the next morning, involved inserting a stent to open up the blocked artery. My family and I waited anxiously in the waiting room. The cardiologist, Dr. Reddy, assured us that the procedure had a high success rate, but it was still a nerve-wracking experience. The consent form mentioned risks like bleeding and infection, and the estimated cost was Rs. 3.5 lakhs.
normalised: He was immediately prepped for an angioplasty. The procedure, scheduled for eight A.M. the next morning, involved inserting a stent to open up the blocked artery. unnormalised: The angioplasty was successful. Within a few days, Grandpa was sitting up in bed, chatting and joking. He was put on a cocktail of medications: aspirin 75mg, clopidogrel 75mg OD, atorvastatin 20mg HS, and a beta-blocker. Dr. Reddy emphasized the importance of lifestyle changes: a low-sodium diet, regular exercise, and stress management.
normalised: The angioplasty was successful. Within a few days, Grandpa was sitting up in bed, chatting and joking. He was put on a cocktail of medications: aspirin seventy five milligram, clopidogrel seventy five milligram O-D, atorvastatin twenty milligram H-S, and a beta-blocker. Doctor Reddy emphasized the importance of lifestyle changes: a low-sodium diet, regular exercise, and stress management.

unnormalised: Over the next few months, he diligently followed the doctor's advice. He even joined a cardiac rehab program at the hospital, attending sessions thrice a week. He learned about healthy eating, exercised under supervision, and received emotional support from other patients. He started feeling better than he had in years.

unnormalised: Now, a year later, Grandpa is back to his old self, albeit a more health-conscious version. He still enjoys his daily chai, but he's replaced the biscuits with a handful of almonds. He walks religiously every morning. And most importantly, he's living proof that even after a serious cardiac event, a full and active life is possible with timely intervention and dedicated self-care. He has follow up appointments scheduled with Dr. Reddy every 6 months.
